awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Framework: Data: HDR: Nanocomposites to Metamaterials: A Knowledge Graph Framework
awd_abstract_narration:
A team of experts from four universities (Duke, RPI, Caltech and Northwestern) creates an open source data resource for the polymer nanocomposites and metamaterials communities.  A broad spectrum of users will be able to query the system, identify materials that may have certain characteristics, and automatically produce information about these materials.  The new capability (MetaMine) is based on previous work by the research team in nanomaterials (NanoMine).  The effort focuses upon two significant domain problems: discovery of factors controlling the dissipation peak in nanocomposites, and tailored mechanical response in metamaterials motivated by an application to personalize running shoes.  The project will significantly improve the representation of data and the robustness with which user communities can identify promising materials applications.   By expanding interaction of the nanocomposite and metamaterials communities with curated data resources, the project enables new collaborations in materials discovery and design.  Strong connections with the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), the Air Force Research Laboratory (AFRL), and Lockheed Martin facilitate industry and government use of the resulting knowledge base. 

The project develops an open source Materials Knowledge Graph (MKG) framework.  The framework for materials includes extensible semantic infrastructure, customizable user templates, semi-automatic curation tools, ontology-enabled design tools and custom user dashboards.  The work generalizes a prototype data resource (NanoMine) previously developed by the researchers, and demonstrates the extensibility of this framework to metamaterials.  NanoMine enables annotation, organization and data storage on a wide variety of nanocomposite samples, including information on composition, processing, microstructure and properties.  The extensibility will be demonstrated through creation of a MetaMine module for metamaterials, parallel to the NanoMine module for nanocomposites.  The frameworks will allow for curation of data sets and end-user discovery of processing-structure-property relationships.  The work supports the Materials Genome Initiative by creating an extensible data ecosystem to share and re-use materials data, enabling faster development of materials via robust testing of models and application of analysis tools.  The capability will be compatible with the NIST Material Data Curator System, and the team also engages both AFRL and Lockheed Martin to facilitate industry and government use of the resulting knowledge base. 

This award by the Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure is jointly supported by the Division of Materials Research within the NSF Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Unlocking the Future of Materials with MaterialsMine

What Was This Project About?
Imagine if scientists around the world could easily share, find, and use each other’s data to speed up the discovery of new materials—like super-strong composites, flexible electronics, or materials that can “morph” into different shapes. That’s exactly what this project set out to do. Our team created an online platform called MaterialsMine.org, designed to make materials data easy to access, understand, and reuse.

MaterialsMine.org is like a giant digital library, but instead of books, it holds data about advanced materials. It’s built on principles known as FAIR—meaning the data is Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable. This helps scientists from different fields work together more effectively.

What Did Our Team Build?

  • An Ontology and a Knowledge Graph for materials data - containing definitions, linkages and structures that allow materials data to be flexibly stored.

  • NanoMine: A collection of data about polymer nanocomposites—materials made by mixing plastics with tiny particles to make them stronger or conductive.

  • MetaMine: Focuses on metamaterials, which are specially engineered to have unique properties, like bending light or sound in unusual ways.

Both NanoMine and MetaMine are packed with carefully organized information from scientific studies. To help researchers get the most out of this data, the team developed special tools such as:

  • ChemProps & Dynamfit: Make it easier to standardize material names and prepare data for analysis.

  • Microstructure Characterization Tools: Analyze images of materials to understand how their structure affects their properties.

  • 3D Simulation Tools: Allow users to create new designs of composites or metamaterials with special properties, or that can be 3D printed.

We also created smart tools that use artificial intelligence to automatically pull useful information from scientific papers, reports and files — approaching automation for data curation.

Why Does This Matter?
MaterialsMine is designed to help students, educators, researchers and industry professionals. By making real-world data available and easy to use, MaterialsMine:

  • Empowers Students to learn data analysis skills with hands-on projects.

  • Supports Researchers in discovering new materials faster.

  • Builds a Community of scientists who share data, tools, and ideas.

The project’s impact has been felt through workshops, tutorials, and special issues in scientific journals, where researchers contributed their own data to MaterialsMine. By promoting open data sharing, this project is helping to create a future where scientific discoveries happen faster, more collaboratively, and more transparently.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 02/11/2025
Modified by: Lynda Catherine Brinson

Image
  • Conceptual schematic of the structure and function of MaterialsMine including data ingestion, structure and query/visualization capabilities for materials knowledge on nanocomposites and metamaterials.
    LC Brinson, M Deagen
    Creative Commons
    Lynda Catherine Brinson
    Overview of MaterialsMine

Unlocking the Future of Materials with MaterialsMine


What Was This Project About?
Imagine if scientists around the world could easily share, find, and use each others data to speed up the discovery of new materialslike super-strong composites, flexible electronics, or materials that can morph into different shapes. Thats exactly what this project set out to do. Our team created an online platform called MaterialsMine.org, designed to make materials data easy to access, understand, and reuse.


MaterialsMine.org is like a giant digital library, but instead of books, it holds data about advanced materials. Its built on principles known as FAIRmeaning the data is Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable. This helps scientists from different fields work together more effectively.


What Did Our Team Build?




An Ontology and a Knowledge Graph for materials data - containing definitions, linkages and structures that allow materials data to be flexibly stored.




NanoMine: A collection of data about polymer nanocompositesmaterials made by mixing plastics with tiny particles to make them stronger or conductive.




MetaMine: Focuses on metamaterials, which are specially engineered to have unique properties, like bending light or sound in unusual ways.




Both NanoMine and MetaMine are packed with carefully organized information from scientific studies. To help researchers get the most out of this data, the team developed special tools such as:




ChemProps & Dynamfit: Make it easier to standardize material names and prepare data for analysis.




Microstructure Characterization Tools: Analyze images of materials to understand how their structure affects their properties.




3D Simulation Tools: Allow users to create new designs of composites or metamaterials with special properties, or that can be 3D printed.




We also created smart tools that use artificial intelligence to automatically pull useful information from scientific papers, reports and files  approaching automation for data curation.


Why Does This Matter?
MaterialsMine is designed to help students, educators, researchers and industry professionals. By making real-world data available and easy to use, MaterialsMine:




Empowers Students to learn data analysis skills with hands-on projects.




Supports Researchers in discovering new materials faster.




Builds a Community of scientists who share data, tools, and ideas.




The projects impact has been felt through workshops, tutorials, and special issues in scientific journals, where researchers contributed their own data to MaterialsMine. By promoting open data sharing, this project is helping to create a future where scientific discoveries happen faster, more collaboratively, and more transparently.
